title: U.S. commerce secretary warns India not to allow Huawei in its 5G networks
text:
In New Delhi on Thursday, Wilbur Ross warned his host country not to “inadvertently subject itself to untoward security risk” by using the Chinese telecom’s equipment in its 5G network. Airtel and Vodafone Idea, two of India’s largest wireless carriers, currently use Huawei equipment. (Financial Times)

Talking point: As the U.S. restricts Chinese companies’ growth in its market—and vice versa—India’s tech sector has become the battleground for a proxy war between the two superpowers. Chinese and U.S. funds and strategic investors are trading off the biggest venture capital rounds for Indian startups. They spent US$2.8 billion and US$1.8 billion, respectively, in 2017, a trend that shows no sign of abating: Alibaba’s Ant Financial is reportedly set to lead a US$600-million investment round in Zomato, which would value the Indian food-delivery company at more than US$4 billion. The deal would complement Ant’s 40 per cent stake in Paytm, an Indian payments and e-commerce marketplace company. Alibaba also has an interest in ride-hailing app Ola via its investor Didi Chuxing; Ola’s other backers include Tencent. The result is a Chinese-backed consumer app ecosystem to compete with U.S. firms Amazon and Uber, which operate e-commerce, ride hailing or food delivery under their own brands in India. Platforms like Netflix and Facebook’s WhatsApp are also testing new features in the country. The foreign interest is running up against the Indian government’s economic nativism. In December 2018, Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government imposed e-commerce rules that targeted Amazon and Walmart-owned Flipkart. On Thursday, Ross blamed the restrictions for the former significantly reducing its investment in India this year. Google and U.S. tech-sector associations also oppose India’s proposed data localization laws. But all those rules benefit Reliance, which is launching an e-commerce platform based on wireless usage data from its Jio carrier—the kind of national champion the Modi government is keen to promote. A Huawei ban will cost Airtel and Vodafone at a time when they’re losing users and money in a price war to Jio.
